annotation.TEXT: *Insert "not the bees!" joke here* - In all seriousness though, it's easier to just run past this section rather than dealing with these enemies, especially since there's a large health pick-up towards the end.

Hard Man fights relatively the same as he did before, only now there's an added gimmick of falling rocks. They only fall whenever a Crash Bomb detonates or when Hard Man himself slams into the ground. Either way, they don't really make this fight any more difficult (and they actually kind of help with avoiding the Hard Knuckles at times).

Then again, this isn't too much of an issue if you have another Robot Master before selecting him. As seen here, you can now switch between RM's once you complete their stages. It's definitely a neat mechanic that allows for way more options when dealing with certain enemies or stage hazards.

As you can probably tell, I'm also doing this playthrough with custom music as well. Admittedly, I tried to do a playthrough of this game a while back, which would have used custom tracks for every part of the game. I never got around to completing it, but since I'm playing it anyways for my Subscriber Vote Special, I figured I may as well bring back the idea and finish it properly this time.

I'm going to warn you all right now: Needle Man isn't one of my better bosses. To be honest, the whole boss set of MM3 (with the exception of Top Man) seems to give me more trouble than almost any of the others in the series, and I have no idea why that is. It's not like they have hard patterns or anything, but I'm just not that good at avoiding their attacks.

To what's probably no one's surprise: Metal Man is one of the more useful Robot Masters in the game. His Metal Blades are still just as deadly and spamable as ever, though they do have some restrictions as well. Aside from the standard 3 shots per-screen limit, the blades can no longer go through walls. Instead, they actually cling on to surfaces and travel along them. It's a somewhat odd trait for them, but it can actually be rather helpful.

Now that the first game is out of the way, it's time to move on to the sequel. Thankfully, much like with Rockman Infinite 2, the creators seemed to learn their lesson in between games. Limelight 2 does everything right that the first game got wrong, and even adds some new mechanics in the process.

Almost every stage has some new gimmicks relating to the Robot Master's abilities. Here, it's these globs that turn into platforms if you shoot them or if they fall on another surface. It's a bit tricky to get used to them at first, but they're not too difficult to get by (plus, they don't seem to show up that often either).

Quick Man is on-par with Metal Man in terms of general usefulness (again, probably no surprise there). His boomerangs function like the version Mega Man obtains, rather than firing out in three's and homing in on enemies. To be honest, I'm fine with this aspect, since his real traits are in his movements. Given the obvious, he can run faster and jump much higher than the other RM's, making it very easy to abuse his speed to get through levels quickly (which I won't be doing for the most part).

The squiggly things are the secret objects of this game. There's actually 12 of them in total, and collecting them all actually yields a very interesting reward. I'll go into more detail on it when I eventually get all of them.

Time for the main rundown: Much like in the first game, each stage puts you in control of a specific Robot Master. Unlike the first game however, the RM's aren't overly limited anymore. Each one has some form of unique ability or trait that sets them all apart, to which the stages are also designed to take full advantage of.

Despite being the holder of one of the worst weapons in MM2, Crash Man actually plays pretty decently here. Aside from having an unlimited supply of Crash Bombs, the explosions they emit deal constant damage to nearly anything they touch. He can also fire them at a downwards angle while jumping (although this is the only way he can fire while in the air). However, all of this isn't without its flaws. You can only have one Crash Bomb on-screen at a time, and you still have to wait for it to explode before firing another.

Shadow Man's room now has those arrow blocks that redirect projectiles. Since these are embedded on the ceiling, they're really only there for Shadow Man to use for his new attack. Beyond that, not much else has changed with him.
BGM: Auto's Shop - Mega Man Eternal Composer: Kevin
Just to note, there's actually a relatively long wait time before you warp out of the level after beating a boss. For the sake of convenience, I shortened these sequences with a bit of editing.

For the most part, I'll be using remixes from RushJet1's "Mega Man 3 Remade" album. There will be a few times where I'll use other tracks (in which case, I'll list its name at the bottom of the screen), but for the most part, I'll be using music that fits with the pure 8-bit standards (at least, whenever possible).
